model.dek: Step aside spaghetti. There's a new look in pasta.
model.promoDek: Step aside spaghetti. There's a new look in pasta.
model.promoHed: The Modern Way to Eat Pasta
model.seoDescription: These modern pasta recipes include squid ink pasta, lobster sauces, and calamari.
model.socialDescription: Pasta's got a brand new look.

items.caption: Lobster, cream, and pasta. Why hasn't this always been a thing?
Chickpeas and chorizo are such a great combination for this updated meat sauce. The chickpeas give the sauce a nutty undertone while the chorizo turns up the heat.
Pesto doesn't have to be green. This roasted tomato and almond pesto is quick and herb-free, with a whole different kind of flavor.
The most modern part about this crab pasta? Besides boiling the water, there is no cooking required. That's a modern comfort you can get used to.
Calamari is great, but you know what's even better? Calamari on top of pasta. This simple-but-genius change gives a crispy coat and rich seafood flavor.

Sure, you could find this casarecce in Sicily, but how many people are actually making this sweet-and-savory combination anywhere else? Topping the pasta with golden raisins and pine nuts gives this swordfish and tomato dish an entirely new dimension. It may just turn into the favorite you never knew you had.
Packed with green herbs, briny green olives, and anchovies, this pasta may shoot your taste buds into the next century.
"Will it gnocchi" is the question. In the case of this butternut squash recipe, the answer is "yes." Get ready to crave seconds.
Why use squash? Why not? This modernist take on pasta carbonara takes on some additional heartiness with seasonal delicata squash stirred in.
Pasta can be gluten-free and good: that's the miracle of the 21st century. Don't believe us? Scrape another spoonful of ricotta, roasted beets, and pistachios.

'Nduja, the spreadable sausage, is definitely having a moment. Keep turning heads by serving it with some bold squid ink pasta. If you're in a pinch for 'nduja, just add an extra glug of olive oil along with some red pepper flakes.
Shiitake mushrooms are more common in Japanese cuisine; here, they lend their characteristic savory depth to a springy asparagus fettuccine. Sure it's unorthodox, but who says that's a bad thing?

fields.caption: Fettuccine with Shiitakes and Asparagus
fields.credit: Peden and Munk Taylor and Jen
fields.title: Fettuccine with Shiitakes and Asparagus

imageSocial.caption: Fettuccine with Shiitakes and Asparagus
imageSocial.credit: Peden and Munk Taylor and Jen
imageSocial.title: Fettuccine with Shiitakes and Asparagus

photosTout.caption: Fettuccine with Shiitakes and Asparagus
photosTout.credit: Peden and Munk Taylor and Jen
photosTout.title: Fettuccine with Shiitakes and Asparagus

nextGallery.dek: Sometimes you just need a splash of heavy cream.
nextGallery.promoDek: Sometimes you just need a splash of heavy cream.

items.caption: Slow-cooked leeks add sweetness to this creamy, rich pasta.
It's hard to deny: this fierce black squid ink pasta is a showstopper.
Buttery lobster makes anything feel a bit more special, especially when tossed with burst cherry tomatoes and served over spaghetti.
This recipe makes a lot of anchovy butter and that's a good thing. Save the leftovers to sear steak, toss with roasted vegetables, or add to mashed potatoes.
When braised low and slow, intensely flavored oxtail cooks down to become tender and silky.
A sprinkling of poppy seeds adds surprising pops of color and crunch.
The cubes of mozzarella melt into this pasta, creating gooey bites of smoky goodness.
What makes this the smoothest, richest carbonara ever? That would be the seven eggs yolks in the sauce.
The secret weapon in this weeknight-friendly pasta is anchovies, which add a salty, briny kick.
Swapping in oat milk and cashew butter for heavy cream cuts down the added fat and calories without sacrificing decadence.
There's a boatload of mussels, clams, and shrimp in this garlicky pasta and we're not complaining.
A few glugs of heavy cream turn this ordinary pasta into anything but.
Why just eat fried calamari on its own when you can toss it with spaghetti instead?

nextGallery.seoDescription: Sometimes you just need a splash of heavy cream.
nextGallery.socialDescription: Sometimes you just need a splash of heavy cream.

items.dek: There's something special about lobster you've prepared yourself, but if cooking one on a weeknight isn't your speed, buy cooked lobster or shrimp instead.
items.promoDek: There's something special about lobster you've prepared yourself, but if cooking one on a weeknight isn't your speed, buy cooked lobster or shrimp instead.

items.dek: As co-chefs, Hudman and Ticer see each other daily, but the old friends still cook together on days off. "Andy does the steak," says Hudman, "and I do the pasta."
items.promoDek: As co-chefs, Hudman and Ticer see each other daily, but the old friends still cook together on days off. "Andy does the steak," says Hudman, "and I do the pasta."

items.dek:
For perfect gnocchi, don't work the
dough too much and add as little flour as possible.
It's okay if the dough is a little sticky.
